div.p: The troublesome reign and lamentable death of Edward the second, King of England: with the tragical fall of proud Mortimer:
As it was sundry times publicly acted in the honourable city of London, by the right honourable the Earl of Pembroke his servants. Written by Chri Marlowe gent.
Imprinted at London for William Jones dwelling near Holborn conduit, at the sign of the gunne.. 1594.

div.head: The troublesome reign and lamentable death of Edward the second, King of England: with the tragical fall of proud Mortimer.
div.stage: Enter Gavestone reading on a letter that was brought him from the King.
div.l: My father is deceased, come Gaveston,
And share the kingdom with thy dearest friend
Ah words that make me surfeit with delight:
What greater bliss can hap to Gaveston,
Then live and be the favourite of a King?
Sweet prince I come, these these thy amorous lines,
Might have enforced me to have swum from France,
And like Leander gasped upon the sand,
So thou wouldst smile and take me in thy arms.
The sight of London to my exiled eyes,
Is as Elysium to a new come soul,
Not that I love the city or the men,
But that it harbours him I hold so dear,
The King, upon whose bosom let me die,
And with the world be still at enmity:
What need the Arctic people love starlight,
To whom the sun shines both by day and night.
Farewell base stooping to the lordly peers,
my knee shall bow to none but to the King,
As for the multitude that are but sparks,
Raked up in embers of their poverty,
Tauti: I'll fan first on the wind,
That glanceth at my lips and flieth away;
But how now, what are these?

sp.speaker: Poor men.
sp.l: Such as desire your worship's service.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: What canst thou do?

sp.speaker: 1. poor.
sp.l: I can ride.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: But I have no horses. What art thou?

sp.speaker: 2. poor.
sp.l: A traveller.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: Let me see, thou wouldst do well
To wait at my trencher, and tell me lies at dinner time,
And as I like your discoursing, I'll have you.
And what art thou?

sp.speaker: 3. poor.
sp.l: A soldier, that hath served against the scot.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: Why there are hospitals for such as you,
I have no war, and therefore sir be gone.

sp.speaker: Seld.
sp.l: Farewell, and perish by a soldier's hand,
That wouldst reward them with an hospital.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Ay, ay, these words of his move me as much,
As if a goose should play the porpentine,
And dart her plumes, thinking to pierce my breast,
But yet it is no pain to speak men fair,
I'll flatter these, and make them live in hope:
You know that I came lately out of France,
And yet I have not viewed my lord the King,
If I speed well, I'll entertain you all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: I have some business, leave me to myself.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We will wait here about the court. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: Do: these are not men for me,
I must have wanton poets, pleasant wits,
Musicians, that with touching of a string
May draw the pliant King which way I please:
Music and poetry is his delight,
Therefore I'll have Italian masks by night,
Sweet speeches, comedies, and pleasing shows,
And in the day when he shall walk abroad,
Like sylvan nymphs my pages shall be clad,
My men like satires grazing on the lawns,
Shall with their goat feet dance an antic hay,
Sometime a lovely boy in Diane's shape,
With hair that gilds the water as it glides,
Crownets of pearl about his naked arms,
And in his sportful hands an olive tree,
To hide those parts which men delight to see,
Shall bathe him in a spring, and there hard by,
One like Actaeon peeping through the grove,
Shall by the angry goddess be transformed,
And running in the likeness of an hart,
By yelping hounds pulled down, and seem to die,
Such things as these best please his majesty.
My lord, here comes the King and the nobles
From the parliament, I'll stand aside.

div.stage: Enter the King, Lancaster, Mortimer senior, Mortimer junior, Edmund Earl of Kent, Guy Earl of Warwick, etc.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Lancast.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: That Earl of Lancaster do I abhor.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Will you not grant me this? in spite of them
I'll have my will, and these two Mortimers,
That cross me thus, shall know I am displeased.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: If you love us my lord, hate Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: That villain Mortimer I'll be his death.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Mine uncle here, this Earl, and I myself,
Were sworn to your father at his death,
That he should ne'er return into the realm:
And know my lord, ere I will break my oath,
This sword of mine that should offend your foes,
Shall sleep within the scabbard at thy need,
And underneath thy banners march who will,
For Mortimer will hang his armour up.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: Mort. dieu.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Well Mortimer, I'll make thee rue these words,
Beseems it thee to contradict thy King?
Frown'st thou thereat aspiring Lancaster,
The sword shall plane the furrows of thy brows,
And hew these knees that now are grown so stiff,
I will have Gaveston, and you shall know,
What danger 'tis to stand against your King.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: Well done, Ned.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My lord, why do you thus incense your peers,
That naturally would love and honour you:
But for that base and obscure Gaveston,
Four earldoms have I besides Lancaster,
Derby, Salisbury, Lincoln, Leicester,
These will I sell to give my soldiers pay,
Ere Gaveston shall stay within the realm,
Therefore if he be come, expel him straight.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Barons and Earls, your pride hath made me mute,
But now I'll speak, and to the proof I hope:
I do remember in my father's days,
Lord Percy of the North being highly moved,
Braved Mowbry in presence of the King,
For which, had not his highness loved him well,
He should have lost his head, but with his look,
The undaunted spirit of Percy was appeased,
And Mowbry and he were reconciled:
Yet dare you brave the King unto his face,
Brother revenge it, and let these their heads,
Preach upon poles for trespass of their tongues.

sp.speaker: Warwick.
sp.l: O our heads.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I yours, and therefore I would wish you grant.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Bridle thy anger gentle Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: I cannot, nor I will not, I must speak,
Cousin, our hands I hope shall fence our heads,
And strike off his that makes you threaten us.
Come uncle, let us leave the brainsick King,
And henceforth parley with our naked swords.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Wiltshire hath men enough to save our heads.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: All Warwickshire will love him for my sake.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: And northward Gaveston hath many friends,
Adieu my lord, and either change your mind,
Or look to see the throne where you should sit,
To float in blood, and at thy wanton head,
The glozing head of thy base minion thrown.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I cannot brook these haughty menaces:
Am I a King and must be over ruled?
Brother display my ensigns in the field,
I'll bandy with the barons and the Earls,
And either die, or live with Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: I can no longer keep me from my lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: What Gaveston, welcome: kiss not my hand,
Embrace me Gaveston as I do thee:
Why shouldst thou kneel,
Knowest thou not who I am?
Thy friend, thyself, another Gaveston,
Not Hilas was more mourned of Hercules,
Than thou hast been of me since thy exile.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: And since I went from hence, no soul in hell
Hath felt more torment than poor Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I know it, brother welcome home my friend,
Now let the treacherous Mortimers conspire,
And that high minded Earl of Lancaster,
I have my wish, in that I joy thy sight,
And sooner shall the sea o'er whelm my land,
Then bear the ship that shall transport thee hence:
I here create thee lord high chamberlain,
Chief secretary to the state and me,
Earl of Cornwall, King and lord of man.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: My lord, these titles far exceed my worth.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Brother, the least of these may well suffice
For one of greater birth than Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Cease brother, for I cannot brook these words,
Thy worth sweet friend is far above my gifts,
Therefore to equal it receive my heart,
If for these dignities thou be envied,
I'll give thee more, for but to honour thee,
Is Edward pleased with kingly regiment.
Fearest thou thy person? thou shalt have a guard:
Wants thou gold? go to my treasury,
Wouldst thou be loud and feared? receive my seal,
Save or condemn, and in our name command,
What so thy mind affects or fancy likes.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: It shall suffice me to enjoy your love,
Which whiles I have, I think myself as great,
As Caesar riding in the Roman street,
With captive Kings at his triumphant car.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Whether goes my lord of Coventry so fast?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: To celebrate your father's exequies,
But is that wicked Gaveston returned?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I priest, and lives to be revenged on thee,
That wert the only cause of his exile.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: 'Tis true, and but for reverence of these robes,
Thou shouldst not plod one foot beyond this place.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I did no more than I was bound to do,
And Gaveston unless thou be reclaimed,
As than I did incense the parliament,
So will I now, and thou shalt back to France.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: Saving your reverence, you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Throw of his golden mitre, rend his stole,
And in the channel christen him a new.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Ah brother, lay not violent hands on him,
For he'll complain unto the see of Rome.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: Let him complain unto the sea of hell,
I'll be revenged on him for my exile.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: No, spare his life, but seize upon his goods,
Be thou lord Bishop, and receive his rends,
And make him serve thee as thy chaplain,
I give him thee, here use him as thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: He shall to prison, and there die in bolts.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I to the tower, the fleet, or where thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: For this offence be thou accursed of God.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Who's there? convey this priest to the tower.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: True, true.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: But in the mean time Gaveston away,
And take possession of his house and goods,
Come follow me, and thou shalt have my guard,
To see it done, and bring thee safe again.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: What should a priest do with so fair a house?
A prison may beseem his holiness.

div.stage: Enter both the Mortimers, Warwick, and Lancaster.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: 'Tis true, the Bishop is in the tower,
And goods and body given to Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What? will they tyrannize upon the church?
Ah wicked King, accursed Gaveston,
This ground which is corrupted with their steps,
Shall be their timeless sepulchre, or mine.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Well, let that peevish Frenchman guard him sure
Unless his breast be sword proof he shall die.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: How now, why droops the Earl of Lancaster?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Wherefore is Guy of Warwick discontent?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: That villain Gaveston is made an Earl.

sp.speaker: Mortim. senior
sp.l: An Earl!

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ay, and besides, lord chamberlain of the realm,
And secretary to, and lord of man.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: We may not, nor we will not suffer this.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Why post we not from hence to levy men?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My lord of Cornwall, now at every word,
And happy is the man, whom he vouchsafes
For vailing of his bonnet one good look,
Thus arm in arm, the King and he doth march:
Nay more, the guard upon his lordship waits:
And all the court begins to flatter him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Thus leaning on the shoulder of the King.
He nods, and scorns, and smiles at those that pass.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Doth no man take exceptions at the slave?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: All stomach him, but none dare speak a word.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Ah that bewrays their baseness Lancaster,
Were all the Earls and barons of my mind,
We'll hale him from the bosom of the King,
And at the court gate hang the peasant up,
Who swollen with venom of ambitious pride,
Will be the ruin of the realm and us.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Here comes my lord of Canterbury's grace.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: His countenance bewrays he is displeased.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: First were his sacred garments rent and torn,
Then laid they violent hands upon him next,
Himself imprisoned, and his goods asseized,
This certify the Pope, away take horse.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My lord, will you take arms against the King?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What need I, God himself is up in arms,
When violence is offered to the church.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Then will you join with us that be his peers
To banish or behead that Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What else my lords, for it concerns me near,
The bishopric of Coventry is his.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Madam, whether walks your majesty so fast?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Unto the forest gentle Mortimer,
To live in grief and baleful discontent,
For now my lord the King regards me not,
But dotes upon the love of Gaveston,
He claps his cheeks, and hangs about his neck,
Smiles in his face, and whispers in his ears,
And when I come, he frowns, as who should say,
Go whether thou wilt seeing I have Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Is it not strange, that he is thus bewitched?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Madam, return unto the court again:
that sly inveigling Frenchman we'll exile,
Or lose our lives: and yet ere that day come,
The King shall lose his crown, for we have power,
And courage to, to be revenged at full.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: But yet lift not your swords against the King.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No, but we'll lift Gaveston from hence.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And war must be the means, or he'll stay still.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then let him stay, for rather than my lord
Shall be oppressed by civil mutinies,
I will endure a melancholy life,
And let him frolic with his minion.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: My lords, to ease all this, but hear me speak,
We and the rest that are his counsellors,
Will meet, and with a general consent,
Confirm his banishment with our hands and seals.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What we confirm the King will frustrate.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Then may we lawfully revolt from him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But say my lord, where shall this meeting be?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: At the new temple.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Content:
And in the mean time I'll entreat you all,
To cross to Lambeth, and there stay with me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Come then let's away.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Madam farewell.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Mortimer, and for my sake,
Forbear to levy arms against the King.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Ay, if words will serve, if not, I must.

div.stage: Enter Gaveston and the Earl of Kent.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Edmund the mighty prince of Lancaster,
That hath more earldoms than an ass can bear,
And both the Mortimers two goodly men,
With Guy of Warwick that redoubted knight,
are gone towards Lambeth, there let them remain.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here is the form of Gaveston's exile:
May it please your lordship to subscribe your name.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Give me the paper.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Quick quick my lord,
I long to write my name.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: But I long more to see him banished hence.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: The name of Mortimer shall fright the King,
Unless he be declined from that base peasant.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: What? are you moved that Gaveston sits here?
It is our pleasure, we will have it so.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Your grace doth well to place him by your side,
For nowhere else the new Earl is so safe.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: What man of noble birth can brook this sight?
Quam male conueniunt:
See what a scornful look the peasant casts.

sp.speaker: Penb.
sp.l: Can kingly lions fawn on creeping ants?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Ignoble vassal that like Phaeton,
Aspirest unto the guidance of the sun.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Their downfall is at hand, their forces down,
We will not thus be faced and overpeered.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lay hands on that traitor Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Lay hands on that traitor Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Is this the duty that you owe your King?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: We know our duties, let him know his peers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Whether will you bear him, stay or ye shall die,

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: We are no traitors, therefore threaten not.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: No, threaten not my lord, but pay them home.
Were I a King.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Thou villain, wherefore talks thou of a King,
That hardly art a gentleman by birth?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Were he a peasant being my minion,
I'll make the proudest of you stoop to him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My lord, you may not thus disparage us,
Away I say with hateful Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Mort. senior
sp.l: And with the Earl of Kent that favours him.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Nay, then lay violent hands upon your King,
Here Mortimer, sit thou in Edward's throne,
Warwick and Lancaster, wear you my crown,
Was ever King thus over ruled as I?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Learn then to rule us better and the realm.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: What we have done,
Our heart blood shall maintain.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Think you that we can brook this upstart pride?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Anger and wrathful fury stops my speech.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Why are you moved, be patient my lord,
And see what we your councillors have done.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: My lords, now let us all be resolute,
And either have our wills, or lose our lives.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Meet you for this, proud overdaring peers,
Ere my sweet Gaveston shall part from me,
This I'll shall fleet upon the ocean,
And wander to the unfrequented Ind.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: You know that I am legate to the Pope,
On your allegiance to the see of Rome,
Subscribe as we have done to his exile.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Curse him, if he refuse, and then may we
Depose him and elect another King.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I there it goes, but yet I will not yield,
Curse me, depose me, do the worst you can.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Then linger not my lord but do it straight.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Remember how the Bishop was abused,
Either banish him that was the cause thereof.
Or I will presently discharge these lords,
Of duty and allegiance due to thee.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: It boots me not to threat, I must speak fair,
The legate of the Pope will be obeyed:
My lord, you shall be chancellor of the realm,
Thou Lancaster, high admiral of our fleet,
Young Mortimer and his uncle shall be Earls,
And you lord Warwick, president of the North,
And thou of Wales, if this content you not,
Make several kingdoms of this monarchy,
And share it equally amongst you all,
So I may have some nook or corner left,
To frolic with my dearest Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Nothing shall alter us, we are resolved.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Come, come, subscribe.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Why should you love him,
Whom the world hates so?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Because he loves me more than all the world:
Ah none but rude and savage minded men,
Would seek the ruin of my Gaveston,
You that be noble born should pity him.

sp.speaker: Warwick.
sp.l: You that are princely born should shake him off,
For shame subscribe, and let the loon depart.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Urge him my lord.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Are you content to banish him the realm?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I see I must, and therefore am content,
In steed of ink, I'll write it with my tears.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: The King is lovesick for his minion.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: 'Tis done, and now accursed hand fall off.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Give it me, I'll have it published in the streets.

sp.speaker: Mor. in.
sp.l: I'll see him presently dispatched away.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Now is my heart at ease.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: And so is mine.

sp.speaker: Penb.
sp.l: This will be good news to the common sort.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Be it or no, he shall not linger here.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: How fast they run to banish him I love,
They would not stir, were it to do me good:
Why should a King be subject to a priest?
Proud Rome, that hatchest such imperial grooms,
For these thy superstitious taperlights,
Wherewith thy Antichristian churches blaze,
I'll fire thy crazed buildings, and enforce
The papal towers, to kiss the lowly ground,
With slaughtered priests may Tiber's channel swell
And banks raised higher with their sepulchres:
As for the peers that back the clergy thus,
If I be King, not one of them shall live.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: My lord I hear it whispered everywhere ,
That I am banished, and must fly the land.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: 'Tis true sweet Gaveston, o were it false,
The legate of the Pope will have it so,
And thou must hence, or I shall be deposed,
But I will reign to be revenged of them,
And therefore sweet friend, take it patiently,
Live where thou wilt, I'll send thee gold enough,
And long thou shalt not stay, or if thou dost,
I'll come to thee, my love shall ne'er decline.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: Is all my hope turned to this hell of grief.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Rend not my heart with thy too piercing words
thou from this land, I from myself am banished.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: To go from hence, grieves not poor Gaveston,
But to forsake you, in whose gracious looks
The blessedness of Gaveston remains,
For nowhere else seeks he felicity.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: And only this torments my wretched soul,
That whether I will or no thou must depart:
Be governor of Ireland in my stead,
And there abide till fortune call thee home.
Here take my picture, and let me wear thine,
Oh might I keep thee here, as I do this,
Happy were I, but now most miserable.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: 'Tis something to be pitied of a King.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thou shalt not hence, I'll hide thee Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: I shall be found, and then 'twill grieve me more.

sp.speaker: Edwa.
sp.l: Kind words, and mutual talk, makes our grief greater.
Therefore with dumb embracement let us part,
Stay Gaveston I cannot leave thee thus.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: For every look, my lord drops down a tear,
Seeing I must go, do not renew my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Edwa.
sp.l: The time is little that thou hast to stay,
And therefore give me leave to look my fill,
But come sweet friend, I'll bear thee on thy way.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: The peers will frown.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I pass not for their anger, come let's go,
Oh that we might as well return as go.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Whether goes my lord?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Fawn not on me French strumpet, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: On whom but on my husband should I fawn?

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: On Mortimer, with whom ungentle Queen,
I say no more, judge you the rest my lord.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: In saying this, thou wrongest me Gaveston,
Is't not enough, that thou corrupts my lord,
And art a bawd to his affections,
But thou must call mine honour thus in question?

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: I mean not so, your grace must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thou art too familiar with that Mortimer,
And by thy means is Gaveston exiled,
But I would wish thee reconcile the lords,
Or thou shalt ne'er be reconciled to me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your highness knows, it lies not in my power.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Away then, touch me not, come Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Villain, 'tis thou that robbest me of my lord.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis you that rob me of my lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Speak not unto her, let her droop and pine.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Wherein my lord, have I deserved these words?
Witness the tears that Isabella sheds,
Witness this heart, that sighing for thee breaks,
How dear my lord is to poor Isabell.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: And witness heaven how dear thou art to me.
There weep, for till my Gaveston be repealed,
Assure thyself thou com'st not in my sight.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O miserable and distressed Queen!
Would when I left sweet France and was embarked,
That charming Circe's walking on the waves,
Had changed my shape, or at the marriage day
The cup of Hymen had been full of poison,
Or with those arms that twinned about my neck,
I had been stifled, and not lived to see,
The King my lord thus to abandon me:
Like frantic Juno will I fill the earth,
with ghastly murmur of my sighs and cries,
For never doted Jove on Ganymede,
So much as he on cursed Gaveston,
But that will more exasperate his wrath,
I must entreat him, I must speak him fair,
And be a means to call home Gaveston:
And yet he'll ever dote on Gaveston,
And so am I for ever miserable.

div.stage: Enter the nobles to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Look where the sister of the King of France,
Sits wringing of her hands, and beats her breast.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: The King I fear hath ill entreated her.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Hard is the heart, that injures such a saint.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: I know 'tis long of Gaveston she weeps.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Why? he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Madam, how fares your grace?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ah Mortimer! now breaks the Kings hate forth,
And he confesseth that he loves me not.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Cry quittance madam then, and love not him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No, rather will I die a thousand deaths,
And yet I love in vain, he'll ne'er love me.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Fear ye not madam, now his minions gone,
His wanton humour will be quickly left.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O never Lancaster! I am enjoined,
To sue unto you all for his repeal:
This wills my lord, and this must I perform,
Or else be banished from his highness' presence.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: For his repeal, madam, he comes not back,
Unless the sea cast up his shipwreck body.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And to behold so sweet a sight as that,
There's none here, but would run his horse to death.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: But madam, would you have us call him home?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I Mortimer, for till he be restored,
the angry King hath banished me the court:
And therefore as thou lovest and tenderest me,
Be thou my advocate unto these peers.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: What, would ye have me plead for Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Plead for him he that will, I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And so am I my lord, dissuade the Queen.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O Lancaster, let him dissuade the King,
For 'tis against my will he should return.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Then speak not for him, let the peasant go.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: 'Tis for myself I speak, and not for him.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No speaking will prevail, and therefore cease.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Fair Queen forbear to angle for the fish,
Which being caught, strikes him that takes it dead,
I mean that vile torpedo, Gaveston,
That now I hope floats on the Irish seas.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sweet Mortimer, sit down by me a while,
And I will tell thee reasons of such weight,
As thou wilt soon subscribe to his repeal.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: It is impossible, but speak your mind.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Then thus, but none shall hear it but ourselves.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: My lords albeit the Queen win Mortimer,
Will you be resolute and hold with me?

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Not I against my nephew.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Fear not, the Queens words cannot alter him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: No, do but mark how earnestly she pleads.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And see how coldly his looks make denial.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: She smiles, now for my life his mind is changed.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: I'll rather lose his friendship I, then grant.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Well of necessity it must be so,
My lords, that I abhor base Gaveston,
I hope your honours make no question,
And therefore though I plead for his repeal,
'Tis not for his sake, but for our avail:
nay for the realm's behoof and for the Kings.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Fie Mortimer, dishonour not thyself,
Can this be true 'twas good to banish him?
And is this true to call him home again?
Such reasons make white black, and dark night day.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: My lord of Lancaster, mark the respect.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: In no respect can contraries be true.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yet good my lord, hear what he can allege.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: All that he speaks, is nothing, we are resolved.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Do you not wish that Gaveston were dead?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would he were.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Why then my lord, give me but leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: But nephew, do not play the sophister.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: This which I urge, is of a burning zeal,
To mend the King, and do our country good:
Know you not Gaveston hath store of gold,
Which may in Ireland purchase him such friends,
As he will front the mightiest of us all,
And whereas he shall live and be beloved,
'Tis hard for us to work his overthrow.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Mark you but that my lord of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: But were he here, detested as he is,
How easily might some base slave be suborned,
To greet his lordship with a poniard,
And none so much as blame the murderer,
But rather praise him for that brave attempt,
And in the chronicle, enrol his name,
For purging of the realm of such a plague.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He saith true.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Ay, but how chance this was not done before?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Because my lords, it was not thought upon:
Nay more, when he shall know it lies in us,
To banish him, and then to call him home,
'twill make him vail the topflag of his pride,
And fear to offend the meanest noble man.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: But how if he do not nephew?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Then may we with some colour rise in arms,
For howsoever we have born it out,
'Tis treason to be up against the King,
So shall we have the people of our side,
Which for his father's sake lean to the King,
But cannot brook a night grown mushroom,
Such a one as my lord of Cornwall is,
Should bear us down of the nobility,
And when the commons and the nobles join,
'Tis not the King can buckler Gaveston.
We'll pull him from the strongest hold he hath,
My lords, if to perform this I be slack,
Think me as base a groom as Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: On that condition Lancaster will grant.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And so will Pembroke and I.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: In this I count me highly gratified,
And Mortimer will rest at your command.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And when this favour Isabell forgets,
Then let her live abandoned and forlorn,
But see in happy time, my lord the King,
Having brought the Earl of Cornwall on his way,
Is new returned, this news will glad him much,
Yet not so much as me, I love him more
Than he can Gaveston, would he loved me
But half so much, then were I treble blessed.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: He's gone, and for his absence thus I mourn,
Did never sorrow go so near my heart,
as doth the want of my sweet Gaveston,
And could my crowns revenue bring him back,
I would freely give it to his enemies,
And think I gained, having bought so dear a friend.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hark how he harps upon his minion.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: My heart is as an anvil unto sorrow,
Which beats upon it like the Cyclops hammers,
And with the noise turns up my giddy brain,
And makes me frantic for my Gaveston:
Ah had some bloodless fury rose from hell,
And with my kingly sceptre stroke me dead,
When I was forced to leave my Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Diablo, what passions call you these

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My gracious lord, I come to bring you news.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: That you have parled with your Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: That Gaveston my lord shall be repealed.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Repealed, the news is too sweet to be true.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But will you love me, if you find it so?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: If it be so, what will not Edward do?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: For Gaveston, but not for Isabell.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: For thee fair Queen, if thou lovest Gaveston,
I'll hang a golden tongue about thy neck,
Seeing thou hast pleaded with so good success.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No other jewels hang about my neck
Then these my lord, nor let me have more wealth,
Than I may fetch from this rich treasury:
Oh how a kiss revives poor Isabell.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Once more receive my hand, and let this be,
A second marriage twixt thyself and me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: And may it prove more happy than the first,
My gentle lord, be these nobles fair,
That wait attendance for a gracious look,
And on their knees salute your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Courageous Lancaster, embrace thy King,
And as gross vapours perish by the sun,
Even so let hatred with thy sovereign smile,
Live thou with me as my companion.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: This salutation overioyes my heart.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Warwick, shall be my chiefest counsellor:
These silver hairs will more adorn my court,
Then gaudy silks, or rich embroidery,
Chide me sweet Warwick, if I go astray.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Slay me my lord, when I offend your grace.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: In solemn triumphs, and in public shows,
Pembroke shall bear the sword before the King.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And with this sword, Pembroke will fight for you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: But wherefore walks young Mortimer aside?
Be thou commander of our royal fleet,
Or if that lofty office like thee not,
I make thee here lord marshal of the realm.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: My lord, I'll marshal so your enemies,
As England shall be quiet, and you safe.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: And as for you, lord Mortimer of Chirke,
Whose great achievements in our foreign war,
Deserves no common place, nor mean reward:
Be you the general of the levied troops,
That now are ready to assail the Scots.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: In this your grace hath highly honoured me,
For with my nature war doth best agree.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now is the King of England rich and strong.
Having the love of his renowned peers.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I Isabell, ne'er was my heart so light,
Clerk of the crown, direct our warrant forth,
For Gaveston to Ireland: Beamont fly,
As fast as Iris, or Jove's Mercury.

sp.speaker: Beam
sp.l: It shall be done my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lord Mortimer, we leave you to your charge.
Now let us in, and feast it royally:
Against our friend the Earl of Cornwall comes,
We'll have a general tilt and tournament,
And then his marriage shall be solemnised,
For wot you not that I have made him sure,
Unto our cousin, the Earl of Gloucester's heir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Such news we hear my lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: That day, if not for him. yet for my sake,
Who in the triumph will be challenger,
Spare for no cost, we will requite your love.

sp.speaker: Warwick.
sp.l: In this, or ought, your highness shall command us.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Thanks gentle Warwick, come let's in and revel. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: Nephew, I must to Scotland, thou stayest here,
Leave now to oppose thyself against the King,
Thou seest by nature he is mild and calm,
And seeing his mind so dotes on Gaveston,
Let him without controlment have his will,
The mightiest Kings have had their minions,
Great Alexander loud Ephestion,
The conquering Hector, for Hilas wept,
And for Patroclus' stern Achilles drooped,
And not Kings only, but the wisest men,
The Roman Tully loved octavis,
Grave Socrates, wild Alcibiades:
Then let his grace, whose youth is flexible,
And promiseth as much as we can wish,
Freely enjoy that vain lightheaded Earl,
For riper years will wean him from such toys.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Uncle, his wanton humour grieves not me,
but this I scorn, that one so basely born,
Should by his sovereign's favour grow so pert,
And riot it with the treasure of the realm,
While soldiers mutiny for want of pay,
He wears a lord's revenue on his back,
And Midas like he jets it in the court,
With base outlandish cullions at his heels,
Whose proud fantastic liveries make such show,
As if that Proteus god of shapes appeared,
I have not seen a dapper lack so brisk,
He wears a short Italian hooded cloak,
Larded with pearl, and in his Tuscan cap
A jewel of more value than the crown,
Whiles other walk below, the King and he
From out a window, laugh at such as we,
And flout our train, and jest at our attire:
Uncle, 'tis this that makes me impatient.

sp.speaker: Mor. senior
sp.l: But nephew, now you see the King is changed.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Then so am I, and live to do him service,
But whiles I have a sword, a hand, a heart,
I will not yield to any such upstart.
You know my mind, come uncle let's away.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: Spencer, seeing that our lord th'earl of Gloucester's dead,
Which of the nobles dost thou mean to serve?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Not Mortimer, nor any of his side,
Because the King and he are enemies,
Baldock: learn this of me, a factious lord
Shall hardly do himself good, much less us,
But he that hath the favour of a King,
May with one word, advance us while we live:
the liberal Earl of Cornwall is the man,
On whose good fortune Spencer's hope depends.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: What, mean you then to be his follower?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: No, his companion, for he loves me well,
And would have once preferred me to the King.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: But he is banished, there's small hope of him.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: I for a while, but Baldock mark the end,
A friend of mine told me in secrecy,
That he's repealed, and sent for back again,
And even now, a post came from the court,
With letters to our lady from the King,
And as she read, she smiled, which makes me think,
It is about her lover Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: 'Tis like enough, for since he was exiled,
She neither walks abroad, nor comes in sight:
But I had thought the match had been broke off,
And that his banishment had changed her mind.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Our lady's first love is not wavering,
My life for thine she will have Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: Then hope I by her means to be preferred,
Having read unto her since she was a child.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Then Baldock, you must cast the scholar off,
And learn to court it like a gentleman,
'Tis not a black coat and a little band,
A velvet capped cloak, faced before with serge,
And smelling to a nosegay all the day,
Or holding of a napkin in your hand,
Or saying a long grace at a table's end,
Or making low legs to a noble man,
Or looking downward, with your eye lids close,
And saying, truly an't may please your honour,
Can get you any favour with great men,
You must be proud, bold, pleasant, resolute,
and now and then, stab as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: Spencer, thou knowest I hate such formal toys,
And use them but of mere hypocrisy.
Mine old lord whiles he lived, was so precise,
That he would take exceptions at my buttons,
And being like pins heads, blame me for the bigness,
Which made me curate-like in mine attire,
Though inwardly licentious enough,
And apt for any kind of villainy.
I am none of these common pendants I,
That cannot speak without propterea quod.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: But one of those that saith quandoquidem,
And hath a special gift to form a verb.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: Leave of this jesting, here my lady comes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The grief for his exile was not so much,
As is the joy of his returning home,
This letter came from my sweet Gaveston,
What needst thou love, thus to excuse thyself?
I know thou couldst not come and visit me,
I will not long be from thee though I die:
This argues the entire love of my lord,
When I forsake thee, death seize on my heart,
But rest thee here where Gaveston shall sleep.
Now to the letter of my lord the King,
He wills me to repair unto the court,
And meet my Gaveston: why do I stay,
Seeing that he talks thus of my marriage day?
Who's there, Baldock?
See that my coach be ready, I must hence.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: It shall be done madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: And meet me at the park pale presently:
Spencer, stay you and bear me company,
for I have joyful news to tell thee of,
My lord of Cornwall is a coming over,
And will be at the court as soon as we.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: I knew the King would have him home again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: If all things sort out, as I hope they will,
Thy service Spencer shall be thought upon.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: I humbly thank your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Come lead the way, I long till I am there.

div.stage: Enter Edward, the Queen, Lancaster, Mortimer, Warwick, Pembroke, Kent, attendants.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The wind is good, I wonder why he stays,
I fear me he is wracked upon the sea.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Look Lancaster how passionate he is,
And still his mind runs on his minion.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: How now, what news, is Gaveston arrived?

sp.speaker: Mor. i
sp.l: Nothing but Gaveston, what means your grace?
You have matters of more weight to think upon,
The King of France sets foot in Normandy.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: A trifle, we'll expel him when we please:
But tell me Mortimer, what's thy device,
Against the stately triumph we decreed?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: A homely one my lord, not worth the telling.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Prithee let me know it.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: But seeing you are so desirous, thus it is:
A lofty cedar tree fair flourishing,
On whose top-branches kingly eagles perch,
And by the bark a canker creeps me up,
And gets unto the highest bough of all,
The motto: aeque tandem.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: And what is yours my lord of Lancaster?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: My lord, mines more obscure than Mortimer's,
Pliny reports, there is a flying fish,
which all the other fishes deadly hate,
And therefore being pursued, it takes the air:
No sooner is it up, but there's a foul,
That seizeth it: this fish my lord I bear,
The motto this: undique mors est.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Proud Mortimer, ungentle Lancaster,
Is this the love you bear your sovereign?
Is this the fruit your reconcilement bears?
Can you in words make show of amity,
And in your shields display your rancorous minds?
What call you this but private libelling,
Against the Earl of Cornwall and my brother?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sweet husband be content, they all love you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: They love me not that hate my Gaveston,
I am that cedar, shake me not too much,
And you the eagles, soar ye ne'er so high,
I have the gresses that will pull you down,
And aeque tandem shall that canker cry,
Unto the proudest peer of Brittany:
Though thou compar'st him to a flying fish,
And threatenest death whether he rise or fall,
'Tis not the hugest monster of the sea,
Nor foulest harpy that shall swallow him.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: If in his absence thus he favours him,
What will he do whenas he shall be present?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: That shall we see, look where his lordship comes.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: My Gaveston, welcome to Tinmouth, welcome to thy friend,
Thy absence made me droop, and pine away,
For as the lovers of fair Danae,
When she was locked up in a brazen tower,
desired her more, and waxed outrageous,
So did it sure with me: and now thy sight
Is sweeter far, then was thy parting hence
Bitter and irksome to my sobbing heart.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Sweet lord and King, your speech preventeth mine,
Yet have I words left to express my joy:
The shepherd nipped with biting winter's rage,
Frolicks not more to see the painted spring,
Than I do to behold your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Will none of you salute my Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Salute him? yes welcome lord chamberlain.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Welcome is the good Earl of Cornwall

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Welcome lord governor of the I'll of man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Welcome master secretary.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Brother do you hear them?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Still will these Earls and barons use me thus?

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: My lord I cannot brook these injuries.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ay me poor soul when these begin to jar.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Return it to their throats, I'll be thy warrant.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Base leaden Earls that glory in your birth,
Go sit at home and eat your tenant's beef:
And come not here to scoff at Gaveston,
Whose mounting thoughts did never creep so low,
As to bestow a look on such as you.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Yet I disdain not to do this for you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Treason, treason: where's the traitor?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Here here King: convey hence Gaveston, they'll murder him.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: The life of thee shall salve this foul disgrace.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Villain thy life, unless I miss mine aim.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ah furious Mortimer what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No more than I would answer were he slain.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes more than thou canst answer though he live,
Dear shall you both aby this riotous deed:
Out of my presence, come not near the court.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: I'll not be barred the court for Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: We'll hail him by the ears unto the block.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Look to your own heads, his is sure enough.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Look to your own crown, if you back him thus.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Warwick, these words do ill beseem thy years.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Nay all of them conspire to cross me thus,
But if I live, I'll tread upon their heads,
That think with high looks thus to tread me down,
Come Edmund let's away, and levy men,
'Tis war that must abate these baron's pride.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Let's to our castles, for the King is moved.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Moved may he be, and perish in his wrath.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Cousin it is no dealing with him now,
He means to make us stoop by force of arms,
And therefore let us jointly here protest,
To prosecute that Gaveston to the death.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: By heaven, the abject villain shall not live.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I'll have his blood, or die in seeking it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The like oath Pembroke takes.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And so doth Lancaster:
Now send our heralds to defy the King,
And make the people swear to put him down.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Letters, from whence?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: From Scotland my lord.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why how now cousin, how fares all our friends?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: My uncles taken prisoner by the Scots.

sp.speaker: LaÌ.
sp.l: We'll have him ransomed man, be of good cheer.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: They rate his ransom at five thousand pound,
Who should defray the money, but the King,
Seeing he is taken prisoner in his wars?
I'll to the King.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Do cousin, and I'll bear thee company.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Mean time my lord of Pembroke and myself,
Will to Newcastle here, and gather head.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: About it then, and we will follow you.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Be resolute, and full of secrecy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Cousin, and if he will not ransom him,
I'll thunder such a peal into his ears,
As never subject did unto his King.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Content, I'll bear my part, holl a who's there?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: I marry, such a guard as this doth well.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Lead on the way.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Whither will your lordships?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Whither else but to the King.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.l: His highness is disposed to be alone.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why, so he may, but we will speak to him.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: You may not in my lord.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: May we not.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: How now, what noise is this?
Who have we there, is't you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay, stay my lord, I come to bring you news,
Mine uncles taken prisoner by the Scots.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Then ransom him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: 'Twas in your wars, you should ransom him.

sp.speaker: Mor junior
sp.l: And you shall ransom him, or else.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: What Mortimer, you will not threaten him?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Quiet yourself, you shall have the broad seal,
To gather for him throughout the realm.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Your minion Gaveston hath taught you this.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: My lord, the family of the Mortimers
Are not so poor, but would they sell their land,
Would levy men enough to anger you,
We never beg, but use such prayers as these.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Shall I still be haunted thus?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Nay, now you are here alone, I'll speak my mind.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And so will I, and then my lord farewell.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The idle triumphs, masks, lascivious shows
And prodigal gifts bestowed on Gaveston,
Have drawn thy treasure dry, and made thee weak,
The murmuring commons overstretched hath.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Look for rebellion, look to be deposed,
Thy garrisons are beaten out of France,
And lame and poor, lie groaning at the gates,
The wild Oneyle, with swarms of Irish kerns,
Lives uncontrolled within the English pale,
Unto the walls of York the Scots made road,
And unresisted, drave away rich spoils.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: The haughty Dane commands the narrow seas,
While in the harbour ride thy ships unrigged.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: What foreign prince sends thee ambassadors?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Who loves thee? but a sort of flatterers.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Thy gentle Queen, sole sister to Valois,
Complains, that thou hast left her all forlorn.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Thy court is naked, being bereft of those,
That makes a King seem glorious to the world,
I mean the peers, whom thou shouldst dear love:
Libels are cast again thee in the street,
Ballads and rhymes, made of thy overthrow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The Northern borderers seeing the houses burned
Their wives and children slain, run up and down,
Cursing the name of thee and Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: When wert thou in the field with banner spread?
But once, and then thy soldiers marched like players,
With garish robes, not armour, and thyself
Bedaubed with gold, road laughing at the rest,
Nodding and shaking of thy spangled crest,
Where women's favours hung like labels down.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And thereof came it, that the fleering Scots,
To England's high disgrace, have made this jig,
Maids of England, sore may you mourn,
For your lemons you have lost, at bannocks born,
With a heave and a ho,
What weeneth the King of England,
So soon to have won Scotland,
With a rombelow.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Wigmore shall fly, to set my uncle free.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And when 'tis gone, our swords shall purchase more,
If ye be moved, revenge it as you can,
Look next to see us with our ensigns spread.

sp.speaker: Edwa.
sp.l: My swelling heart for very anger breaks,
How oft have I been baited by these peers?
And dare not be revenged, for their power is great:
Yet, shall the crowing of these cockerels,
Affright a lion? Edward, unfold thy paws,
And let their life's blood slake thy furies hunger:
If I be cruel, and grow tyrannous,
Now let them thank themselves, and rue too late.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My lord, I see your love to Gaveston,
Will be the ruin of the realm and you,
For now the wrathful nobles threaten wars,
And therefore brother banish him for ever.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Art thou an enemy to my Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Ay, and it grieves me that I favoured him.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Traitor be gone, whine thou with Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: So will I, rather than with Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Out of my sight, and trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: No marvel though thou scorn thy noble peers,
When I thy brother am rejected thus. Exit.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Away poor Gaveston, that hast no friend but me,
Do what they can, we'll live in Tinmoth here,
And so I walk with him about the walls,
What care I though the Earls be girt us round,
Here comes she that's cause of all these jars.

div.stage: Enter the Queen, ladies 3, Baldock, and Spencer.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My lord, 'tis thought, the Earls are up in arms.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Ay, and 'tis likewise thought you favour him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thus do you still suspect me without cause.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sweet uncle speak more kindly to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: My lord, dissemble with her, speak her fair.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Pardon me sweet, I forgotten myself.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your pardon is quickly got of Isabell.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The younger Mortimer is grown so brave,
That to my face he threatens civil wars.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Why do you not commit him to the tower?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I dare not, for the people love him well.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Why then we'll have him privily made away.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Would Lancaster and he had both caroused,
A bowl of poison to each others health:
But let them go, and tell me what are these.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Two of my father's servants whilst he lived,
May't please your grace to entertain them now.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Tell me, where wast thou born?
What is thine arms?

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: My name is Baldock, and my gentry
I fetched from Oxford, not from heraldry.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The fitter art thou Baldock for my turn,
Wait on me, and I'll see thou shalt not want.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: I humbly thank your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Knowest thou him Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: I my lord, his name is Spencer, he is well allied,
For my sake let him wait upon your grace,
Scarce shall you find a man of more desert.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Then Spencer wait upon me, for his sake
I'll grace thee with a higher style ere long.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: No greater titles happen unto me,
Than to be favoured of your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Cousin, this day shall be your marriage feast,
And Gaveston, think that I love thee well,
To wed thee to our niece, the only heir
Unto the Earl of Gloster late deceased.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: I know my lord, many will stomach me,
But I respect neither their love nor hate.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: The headstrong barons shall not limit me.
He that I list to favour shall be great:
Come let's away, and when the marriage ends,
Have at the rebels, and their complices.

div.stage: Enter Lancaster, Mortimer, Warwick, Pembroke, Kent.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: My lords, of love to this our native land,
I come to join with you, and leave the King,
And in your quarrel and the realm's behoof,
Will be the first that shall adventure life.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I fear me you are sent of policy,
to undermine us with a show of love.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: He is your brother, therefore have we cause
To cast the worst, and doubt of your revolt.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Mine honour shall be hostage of my truth,
If that will not suffice, farewell my lords.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Stay Edmund, never was Plantagenet
False of his word, and therefore trust we thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But what's the reason you should leave him now?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I have informed the Earl of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And it sufficeth: now my lords know this,
That Gaveston is secretly arrived,
And here in Tinmoth frolics with the King,
Let us with these our followers scale the walls,
And suddenly surprise them unawares.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: I'll give the onset.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And I'll follow thee.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: This tottered ensign of my ancestors,
Which swept the desert shore of that dead sea,
Whereof we got the name of Mortimer,
Will I advance upon this castle walls,
Drums strike alarum, raise them from their sport,
And ring aloud the knell of Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: None be so hardy as to touch the King,
But neither spare you Gaveston, nor his friends.

div.stage: Enter the King and Spencer, to them Gaveston, etc.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: O tell me Spencer, where is Gaveston?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: I fear me he is slain my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: No, here he comes, now let them spoil and kill:
Fly, fly, my lords, the Earls have got the hold,
Take shipping and away to Scarborough,
Spencer and I will post away by land.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: O stay my lord, they will not injure you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I will not trust them, Gaveston away.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Farewell my lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Lady, farewell.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Farewell sweet uncle till we meet again.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Gaveston, and farewell niece.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No farewell, to poor Isabell, thy Queen?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Yes, yes, for Mortimer your lover's sake.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Heavens can witness, I love none but you,
From my embracements thus he breaks away,
Oh that mine arms could close this I'll about,
That I might pull him to me where I would,
Or that these tears that drizzle from mine eyes,
Had power to mollify his stony heart,
That when I had him we might never part.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I wonder how he scaped.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Who's this, the Queen?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I Mortimer, the miserable Queen,
Whose pining heart, her inward sighs have blasted,
And body with continual morning wasted:
These hands are tired, with haling of my lord
From Gaveston, from wicked Gaveston,
And all in vain, for when I speak him fair,
He turns away, and smiles upon his minion.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Cease to lament, and tell us where's the King?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What would you with the King, is't him you seek?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No madam, but that cursed Gaveston,
Far be it from the thought of Lancaster,
To offer violence to his sovereign,
We would but rid the realm of Gaveston,
Tell us where he remains, and he shall die.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He's gone by water unto Scarborough,
Pursue him quickly, and he cannot scape,
The King hath left him, and his train is small.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Forslow no time, sweet Lancaster let's march.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How comes it, that the King and he is parted?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: That this your army going several ways,
Might be of lesser force, and with the power
That he intendeth presently to raise,
Be easily suppressed: and therefore be gone.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Here in the river rides a Flemish hoy,
Let's all aboard, and follow him amain.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The wind that bears him hence, will fill our sails,
Come, come aboard, 'tis but an hours sailing.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Madam, stay you within this castle here.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No Mortimer, I'll to my lord the King.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay, rather sail with us to Scarborough.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You know the King is so suspicious,
As if he hear I have but talked with you,
Mine honour will be called in question,
And therefore gentle Mortimer be gone.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Madam, I cannot stay to answer you,
But think of Mortimer as he deserves.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: So well hast thou deserved sweet Mortimer,
As Isabel could live with thee for ever,
In vain I look for love at Edward's hand,
Whose eyes are fixed on none but Gaveston:
Yet once more I'll importune him with prayers,
If he be strange and not regard my words,
My son and I will over into France,
And to the King my brother there complain,
How Gaveston hath robbed me of his love:
But yet I hope my sorrows will have end,
And Gaveston this blessed day be slain. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Yet lusty lords I have escaped your hands,
Your threats, your larums, and your hot pursuits,
And though divorced from King Edward's eyes,
Yet liveth Pierce of Gaveston unsurprised,
Breathing, in hope (Malgrado all your beards,
That muster rebels thus against your King)
To see his royal sovereign once again.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Upon him soldiers, take away his weapons.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Thou proud disturber of thy country's peace,
Corrupter of thy King, cause of these broils,
Base flatterer, yield, and were it not for shame,
Shame and dishonour to a soldier's name,
Upon my weapons point here shouldst thou fall,
And welter in thy gore.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Monster of men, that like the Greekish strumpet
Trained to arms and bloody wars,
So many valiant knights,
Look for no other fortune wretch than death,
Kind Edward is not here to buckler thee.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Lancaster, why talkest thou to the slave?
Go soldiers take him hence,
For by my sword, his head shall off:
Gaveston, short warning shall serve thy turn:
It is our country's cause,
That here severely we will execute,
Upon thy person: hang him at a bough:

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Soldiers, have him away:
But for thou wert the favourite of a King,
Thou shalt have so much honour at our hands.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: I thank you all my lords, than I perceive,
that heading is one, and hanging is the other,
And death is all.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: How now my lord of Arundel?

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: My lords, King Edward greets you all by me.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Arundel, say your message.

sp.speaker: Aru.
sp.l: His majesty, hearing that you had taken Gaveston,
Intreateth you by me, yet but he may
See him before he dies, for why he says,
And sends you word, he knows that die he shall,
And if you gratify his grace so far,
He will be mindful of the courtesy.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Renowned Edward, how thy name
Revives poor Gaveston.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: No, it needeth not,
Arundel, we will gratify the King
In other matters, he must pardon us in this,
Soldiers away with him.

sp.speaker: Gauest.
sp.l: Why my lord of Warwick,
Will not these delays beget my hopes?
I know it lords, it is this life you aim at,
Yet grant King Edward this.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Shalt thou appoint what we shall grant?
Soldier's away with him:
Thus we'll gratify the King,
We'll send his head by thee, let him bestow
His tears on that, for that is all he gets
Of Gaveston, or else his senseless trunk.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Not so my lord, lest he bestow more cost,
In burying him, than he hath ever earned.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: My lords, it is his majesty's request,
And in the honour of a King he swears,
he will but talk with him and send him back.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: When can you tell? Arundel no, we wot,
He that the care of realm remits,
And drives his nobles to these exigents
For Gaveston, will if he zease him once,
Violate any promise to possess him.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: Then if you will not trust his grace in keep,
My lords, I will be pledge for his return.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: It is honourable in thee to offer this,
But for we know thou art a noble gentleman,
We will not wrong thee so,
To make away a true man for a thief.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: How meanst thou Mortimer? that is over base.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Away base groom, robber of King's renown,
Question with thy companions and thy mates.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My lord Mortimer, and you my lords each one,
To gratify the King's request therein,
Touching the sending of this Gaveston,
Because his majesty so earnestly
Desires to see the man before his death,
I will upon mine honour undertake
To carry him, and bring him back again,
Provided this, that you my lord of Arundel
Will join with me.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Pembroke, what wilt thou do?
Cause yet more bloodshed: is it not enough
That we have taken him, but must we now
Leave him on had-i wist, and let him go?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My lords, I will not over woo your honours,
But if you dare trust Pembroke with the prisoner,
Upon mine oath I will return him back.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: My lord of Lancaster, what say you in this?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why I say, let him go on Pembroke's word.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And you lord Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: How say you my lord of Warwick.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Nay, do your pleasures,
I know how 'twill prove.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Then give him me.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Sweet sovereign, yet I come
To see thee ere I die.

sp.speaker: Warw.
sp.l: Yet not perhaps,
If Warwick's wit and policy prevail.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: My lord of Pembroke, we deliver him you,
Return him on your honour, sound away. Exeunt.

div.stage: Manent Pembroke, Mat. gavest. And Pembroke's men, four soldiers.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My lord, you shall go with me,
My house is not far hence out of the way,
A little, but our men shall go along,
We that have pretty wenches to our wives,
Sir, must not come so near and balk their lips.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis very kindly spoken my lord of Pembroke,
Your honour hath an adamant of power,
To draw a prince.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: So my lord, come hither James,
I do commit this Gaveston to thee,
Be thou this night his keeper, in the morning
We will discharge thee of thy charge, be gone.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Unhappy Gaveston, whether goest thou now.

sp.speaker: Horse boy.
sp.l: My lord, we'll quickly be at Cobham.

div.stage: Enter Gaveston morning, and the Earl of Pembroke's men.

sp.speaker: Gaue.
sp.l: O treacherous Warwick thus to wrong thy friend!

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: I see it is your life these arms pursue.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Weaponless must I fall and die in bands,
Oh must this day be period of my life!
Centre of all my bliss, and ye be men,
Speed to the King.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My lord of Pembroke's men,
Strive you no longer, I will have that Gaveston.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Your lordship doth dishonour to yourself,
And wrong our lord, your honourable friend.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: No James, it is my country's cause I follow,
Go, take the villain, soldiers come away,
We'll make quick work, commend me to your master
My friend, and tell him that I watched it well,
Come, let thy shadow parley with King Edward.

sp.speaker: Gau.
sp.l: Treacherous Earl, shall I not see the King?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: The King of heaven perhaps, no other King, away. Exeunt Warwick and his men, with gavest.
Come fellows, it booted not for us to strive,
We will in haste go certify our lord. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter King Edward and Spencer, with drums and fifes.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I long to hear an answer from the barons
Touching my friend, my dearest Gaveston,
Ah Spencer, not the riches of my realm
Can ransom him, ah he is marked to die,
I know the malice of the younger Mortimer,
Warwick I know is rough, and Lancaster
Inexorable, and I shall never see
My lovely Pierce, my Gaveston again,
The barons overbear me with their pride.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.l: Were I King Edward England's sovereign,
son to the lovely Elinor of Spain,
Great Edward Longshanks issue: would I bear
These braves, this rage, and suffer uncontrolled
These barons thus to beard me in my land,
In mine own realm? my lord pardon my speech,
Did you retain your father's magnanimity?
Did you regard the honour of your name?
You would not suffer thus your majesty
Be counterbuffed of your nobility,
Strike off their heads, and let them preach on poles,
No doubt, such lessons they will teach the rest,
As by their preachments they will profit much,
And learn obedience to their lawful King.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Yea gentle Spencer, we have been too mild,
Too kind to them, but now have drawn our sword,
And if they send me not my Gaveston,
We'll steel it on their crest, and poll their tops.

sp.speaker: Bald.
sp.l: This haught resolve becomes your majesty,
Not to be tied to their affection,
As though your highness were a school boy still,
And must be awed and governed like a child.

div.stage: Enter Hugh Spencer an old man, father to the young Spencer, with his truncheon, and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Spen. pa.
sp.l: Long live my sovereign the noble Edward,
In peace triumphant, fortunate in wars.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Welcome old man, com'st thou in Edward's aid?
Then tell thy prince, of whence, and what thou art.

sp.speaker: Spen. pa.
sp.l: Lo, with a band of bowmen and of pikes,
Brown bills, and targeteers, 400 strong,
Sworn to defend King Edward's royal right,
I come in person to your majesty,
Spencer, the father of Hugh Spencer there,
bound to your highness everlastingly,
For favours done in him, unto us all.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Thy father Spencer?

sp.speaker: Spen. filius.
sp.l: True, and it like your grace,
That powers in lieu of all your goodness shown,
His life my lord, before your princely feet.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Welcome ten thousand times, old man again,
Spencer, this love, this kindness to thy King,
Argues thy noble mind and disposition:
Spencer, I here create thee Earl of Wiltshire,
And daily will enrich thee with our favour,
That as the sunshine shall reflect o'er thee:
Beside, the more to manifest our love,
Because we hear lord bruise doth sell his land,
And that the Mortimers are in hand withal,
Thou shalt have crowns of us, t'out the barons,
And Spenser, spare them not, but lay it on.
Soldier's a largesse, and thrice welcome all.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: My lord, here comes the Queen.

div.stage: Enter the Queen and her son, and Lewne a Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Madam, what news?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: News of dishonour lord, and discontent,
Our friend Lewne, faithful and full of trust,
Informeth us, by letters and by words,
That lord Valois our brother, King of France,
Because your highness hath been slack in homage,
Hath seized Normandy into his hands,
These be the letters, this the messenger.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Welcome Lewne, tush Sib, if this be all,
Valois and I will soon be friends again,
But to my Gaveston: shall I never see,
Never behold thee now? Madam in this matter
we will employ you and your little son,
You shall go parley with the King of France,
Boy, see you bear you bravely to the King,
And do your message with a majesty.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Commit not to my youth things of more weigh
Then fits a prince so young as I to bear,
And fear not lord and father, heaven's great beams
On Atlas' shoulder, shall not lie more safe,
Then shall your charge committed to my trust.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: A boy, this towardness makes thy mother fear
Thou art not marked to many days on earth.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Madam, we will that you with speed be shipped,
And this our son, Lewne shall follow you,
With all the haste we can dispatch him hence,
Choose of our lords to bear you company,
And go in peace, leave us in wars at home.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Unnatural wars, where subjects brave their King,
God end them once, my lord I take my leave,
To make my preparation for France.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: What lord matre. dost thou come alone?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yea my good lord, for Gaveston is dead.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Ah traitors, have they put my friend to death,
Tell me matre. died he ere thou camest,
Or didst thou see my friend to take his death?

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.l: Neither my lord, for as he was surprised,
Begirt with weapons, and with enemies round,
I did your highness' message to them all,
Demanding him of them, entreating rather,
And said, upon the honour of my name,
That I would undertake to carry him
Unto your highness, and to bring him back.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: And tell me, would the rebels deny me that?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Proud recreants.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Yea Spencer, traitors all.

sp.speaker: Matr.
sp.l: I found them at the first inexorable,
The Earl of Warwick would not bide the hearing,
Mortimer hardly, Pembroke and Lancaster
Spoke least: and when they flatly had denied,
Refusing to receive me pledge for him,
The Earl of Pembroke mildly thus bespoke.
My lords, because our sovereign sends for him,
And promiseth he shall be safe returned,
I will this undertake, to have him hence,
And see him redelivered to your hands.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Well, and how fortunes that he came not?

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: Some treason, or some villainy was cause.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The Earl of Warwick seized him on his way,
For being delivered unto Pembroke's men,
Their lord road home, thinking his prisoner safe,
But ere he came, Warwick in ambush lay,
And bore him to his death, and in a trench
Strake off his head, and marched unto the camp.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: A bloody part, flatly against law of arms.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: O shall I speak, or shall I sigh and die!

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: My lord, refer your vengeance to the sword,
Upon these barons, hearten up your men,
Let them not unrevenged murder your friends,
Advance your standard Edward in the field,
And march to sire them from their starting holes.
By earth, the common mother of us all,
By heaven, and all the moving orbs thereof,
By this right hand, and by my father's sword,
And all the honours longing to my crown,
I will have heads, and lives for him as many,
as I have manors, castles, towns, and towers,
Treacherous Warwick, traitorous Mortimer:
If I be England's King, in lakes of gore
Your headless trunks, your bodies will I trail,
That you may drink your fill, and quaff in blood,
And stain my royal standard with the same,
That so my bloody colours may suggest
Remembrance of revenge immortally,
On your accursed traitorous progeny:
You villains that have slain my Gaveston,
And in this place of honour and of trust,
Spencer, sweet Spencer, I adopt thee here,
And merely of our love we do create thee
Earl of Gloster, and lord chamberlain,
Despite of times, despite of enemies.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: My lord, here's is a messenger from the barons,
Desires access unto your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Admit him near.

div.stage: Enter the herald from the barons, with his coat of arms.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Long live King Edward, England's lawful lord.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: So wish not they I wis that sent thee hither,
Thou com'st from Mortimer and his complices,
A ranker rout of rebels never was:
Well, say thy message.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: The barons up in arms, by me salute
Your highness, with long life and happiness,
And bid me say as plainer to your grace,
That if without effusion of blood,
You will this grief have ease and remedy,
That from your princely person you remove
This Spencer, as a putrifying branch,
That deads the royal vine, whose golden leaves
impale your princely head, your diadem,
Whose brightness such pernicious upstarts dim,
Say they, and lovingly advise your grace,
To cherish virtue and nobility,
And have old servitors in high esteem,
And shake off smooth dissembling flatterers:
This granted, they, their honours, and their lives,
Are to your highness vowed and consecrate.

sp.speaker: Spen.
sp.l: A traitors, will they still display their pride?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Away, tarry no answer, but be gone,
Rebels, will they appoint their sovereign
His sports, his pleasures, and his company:
Yet ere thou go, see how I do divorceEmbrace Spencer.
Spencer from me: now get thee to thy lords,
And tell them I will come to chastise them,
For murdering Gaveston: hie thee, get thee gone,
Edward with fire and sword, follows at thy heels,
My lord, perceive you how these rebels swell:
Soldiers, good hearts, defend your sovereign's right,
For now, even now, we march to make them stoop,
Away. Exeunt.

div.stage: Alarms, excursions, a great fight, and a retreat.
Enter the King, Spencer the father, Spencer the son, and the noblemen of the King's side.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Why do we sound retreat? upon them lords,
This day I shall pour vengeance with my sword
On those proud rebels that are up in arms,
And do confront and countermand their King.

sp.speaker: Spen. son.
sp.l: I doubt it not my lord, right will prevail.

sp.speaker: Spen. father
sp.l: 'Tis not amiss my liege for either part,
To breathe a while, our men with sweat and dust
All choked well near, begin to faint for heat,
and this retire refresheth horse and man.

sp.speaker: Spen. son.
sp.l: Here come the rebels.

div.stage: Enter the barons, Mortimer, Lancaster, Warwick, Pembroke, cum caeteris.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Look Lancaster, yonder is Edward among his flatterers.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: And there let him be, till he pay dear for their company.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: And shall or Warwick's sword shall smite in vain.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: What rebels, do you shrink, and sound retreat?

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: No Edward, no, thy flatterers faint and fly.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: They'd best betimes forsake thee and their trains,
For they'll betray thee, traitors as they are.

sp.speaker: Spen. so.
sp.l: Traitor on thy face, rebellious Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Away base upstart, brav'st thou nobles thus.

sp.speaker: Spen. father
sp.l: A noble attempt, and honourable deed,
Is it not trow ye, to assemble aid,
And levy arms against your lawful King?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: For which ere long, their heads shall satisfy,
T'appease the wrath of their offended King.

sp.speaker: Mor. junior
sp.l: Then Edward, thou wilt fight it to the last,
And rather bathe thy sword in subject's blood,
Then banish that pernicious company.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: I traitors all, rather than thus be braved,
Make England's civil towns huge heaps of stones,
And ploughs to go about our palace gates.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: A desperate and unnatural resolution,
Alarum to the fight, saint George for England,
And the barons right.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: S. George for England, and King Edward's right.

div.stage: Enter Edward, with the baron's captives.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: Now lusty lords, now not by chance of war,
But justice of the quarrel and the cause
veiled is your pride, methinks you hang the head
But we'll advance them traitors, now 'tis time
To be avenged on you for all your braves,
And for the murder of my dearest friend,
To whom right well you knew our soul was knit,
Good Pierce of Gaveston my sweet favourite,
A rebels, recreants, you made him away.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Brother, in regard of thee and of thy land,
Did they remove that flatterer from thy throne.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: So sir, you have spoke, away, avoid our presence,
Accursed wretches, was't in regard of us,
When we had sent our messenger to request
He might be spared to come to speak with us,
And Pembroke undertook for his return,
That thou proud Warwick watched the prisoner,
Poor Pierce, and headed him against law of arms,
For which thy head shall over look the rest.
As much as thou in rage out wentest the rest?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Tyrant, I scorn thy threats and menaces,
